sp.l: Well Sir, then ſince you have ſo good a cauſe,
Repoſe your life and honour in the Laws,
Deliver your ſelf unto the State, and I
Will lay my Maces and my Scarlets by,
And from my Office, waving all pretence,
VVill to the State ſubmit my innocence:
Then let the Diett freely try
VVhich is the Traytor, you or I.

sp.speaker: Oſſo.
sp.l: 'Tis bravely ſpoken.

sp.speaker: Lub.
sp.l: Greatly like himſelf!

sp.speaker: Caſſo.
sp.l: Knaviſhly like himſelf.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Agreed, here bind my hands?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My Lord, you ſhall not?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.l: His Propoſition's fair; the Cardinal
Never preach't any thing ſo much Divine,
And let no blood be ſhed, but his or mine.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis all deceit, through you he aims at me,
That he my Fathers Throne might freely invade,
And proudly triumph o're his Royal Shade;
But that he ſhall not do whil'ſt I've a hand
To hold a Spear, and Armies to command.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: And Madam, do you think that fate is amorou?
Or to find any Courtſhip from a bullet?
They like raw travellers court all they meet;
Nor can we ſend a Guide to give advice
VVhom to reſpect, but let 'um take their choice.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Their rugged Courtſhip Sir I ſhan't deny,
Send them abroad, and give them all ſupply,
That may defray the charges of their flight,
Draw bills of death, they ſhall be paid on ſight;
I will your faithful correſpondent be,
And pay as faſt as you can draw on me.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Madam, I'm ſorry you reſolve t' expoſe
Your ſelf, and ſuch a lovely Guard as thoſe,
To all the ſad uncertainties of Fate,
To try your skill in fencing with the State;
For juſtice at a Traytours life doth flie;
And when it makes a paſs, you put it by;
But if the ſword doth hap to run aſtray,
Then thank your ſelf for ſtanding in the way.
sp.stage: Ex. Card. Oſſo. Caſſo Lub. ſhouting, and waving their Fauchions.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Come valiant friends; the talking Prologue's done;
The Curtain's drawn, the mighty Play's begun:
The Muſick of the field in Martial rage
Calls us to enter on this fatal Stage,
Where each brave man ſhall doubly have applauſe,
Crown'd by his courage, and his glorious Cauſe;
A Cauſe more glorious there cannot be,
I for the Kingdom die, and you for me.
sp.stage: Ex. Jul. and Train ſhouting and waving their Poleaxes.
Enter Theodore, and a Surgeon. The Scene the Dukes Chamber.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Offer to let my Maſter go out in this condition?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: I could not hold him Sir, he would go out whether I would or no; but there's no danger, his wound's not great, nor was the arrow venom'd, as firſt you fear'd.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Oh! he'l hear all the news,
And then I tremble at the conſequence.
Now comes this babling raſcal.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Nay, I thought 't would be as I ſaid, the Count is to be King, and marry the Princeſs: How now, where's your Maſter? I've news for him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Get you gone with your news you prating bufflehead, or I'le ſet you down ſtairs; come here with your news?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Prating Bafflehead; and you'l ſet me down ſtairs? do you know who you ſpeak to, Sirrah? come, come, you lie, you lie, you don't know who you ſpeak to, and you'r drunk Sirrah, you would not talk to me at this rate elſe Sirrah; get me down ſtairs with my news Sirrah? I'de have to know, the beſt men in the Kingdom are glad of my intelligence, you drunken raſcal you.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Yes, no doubt you have all the intelligence—pray Mr. Corantoe-Maſter-General, what may your Envoyes and Spies in Forraign Courts coſt you yearly?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: What may they coſt me Sir? pray what may your Envoyes and Spi • s which you maintain with the Duke of Gally-pots, Count Palatine o' Gliſter-pipes, Marqueſs o' Mouth-glue, and Baron o' Bathingtubs, for the ſupport o' your rotten body politick, coſt you yearly? ha, Sir-Ragmanners, my intelligence comes from better men then you or your Maſter either. I met no leſs now (becauſe you prate) then ſix Lords of my old acquaintance coming out of the field together all of a knot.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: What knot? a bow-knot?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: A bow knot ſaucy-chops; when did you ſee ſix Lords tyed of a bow-knot? ha! can you tye your noſe of a bow knot? you had not beſt provoke me ſirrah; but ſo, here comes my man, now it ſhall be ſeen whether I am a lyer or no.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: How, not here! where did we looſe her?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I'le hold a wager the perſon we met in the Cloak was the Duke, and ſhe went after him ſomewhere, and is loſt in the crowd.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Come, come Sir, you Mr. Peagooſe that ſtand peeping there, pray Sir thruſt in your noſe a little further, I have ſome employment for you.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: The Rogue will diſcover all my deſign, and render us ſuſpicious to the Duke's ſervant, I am afraid, come in Alexey and help me to out-face the fool.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Come Sir, did not you hear in the field, as much as to ſay, as if the Count was to be made King, and to marry the Princeſs? come anſwer directly to the point; why don't you ſpeak Sir?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Who, me do you mean?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I, you ſir, who ſhould I mean elſe?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: I hear it, how ſhould I hear it? was I in the field to day?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Why, you impudent ſtinking lying Raſcal, you won't tell me ſuch a lie, will you?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: You miſtake me Landlord, and ha' met ſome body like him.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: No ſir, I don't miſtake; I can ſee, when I ſee, ſurely, I don't carry my eyes in a Hand-basket, and more then that, 'cauſe he goes to't, he's the very man, and no other, from whom I'de all this news now.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Is this your ſix Lords of a knot you Ninny? I ſee you can invent for a need.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Oh, a moſt grievous impertinent lying fellow, I'm ſo plagu'd with him ſometimes!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Hark you Landlord, are not you troubled with a dizzineſs in your Noddle, a Megrim ſometimes; I am afraid you eat too much muſtard, and ſuch hot things.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Some ſnuſh would purge your ſimple brain.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: A little more would make me run diſtracted, don't you tell me,o' your Megrims, your Snuſh, and your Muſtard, a company of Raſcals: Sirrah, did not I meet you coming out o'th' field, and I ask't you what news, 'cauſe I was loath to go farther, 'cauſe I was to go buy a pole o'Ling for the womens dinner that lie in my houſe here; and you told me all this bibble babble, and bid me go no farther, but go to my Lodgers with it, deny't if you dare ſirrah, I'le promiſe you if you do, I'le churn thoſe Buttermilk-chops o' yours, and let your Maſter take it off; I care not if you and your Maſter both get out 〈◊〉 my houſe, I can ha' cuſtomers for my rooms.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Come, enough o' this Landlord.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I han't enough Sir, I won't be made a lyar on

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Why, what a troubleſome fellow art thou?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: And what a troubleſome fellow art thou? I won't be born down by a company o' ſaucy Valets that are good for nothing but to twirle a whisker, and a ſhave the crown o' ſome Sir Nicolas Emptipate his Maſter, and be kickt thrice a day for a caſt ſuit, and Bread and Cheeſe.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Come Landlord, I perceive you are abuſive; this is not to be endured, you muſt be corrected out o' this humor, it will be for your good another day; and now our Maſters backs are turn'd, we'l make bold to give you a taſt of our Parmeſau.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: And I • le give him one lick for the ſake of his Corantoes: Come Sir, ſince you 'r ſo good at Corantoes, pray let's ſee how you can dance a Coranto, come; up with your news quikcly.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Rogues, you won't murder me, will you?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: On the fourteenth inſtant, at the Port of Hucklebone, was drove in by ſtorm a Veſſel call'd the Royal Cudgel bound for back, bum, belly, noddle, or any part of the Kingdom of Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: And near the ſame Port another.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And another laden with Snuſh, for the cure of the Megrim.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: They'l kill their Landlord.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Rogues, Raſcals, Thieves, will you murder me?
Why Surgeon, wilt thou ſtand by and ſee me
Murder'd? I'le lay my death to thee.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: How now Sirrah? do you prate, ſhaver o' ſhin-bones, Drawer of Gum-ſtakes, Grafter o' broken Stilts, Trapanner o' crackt Coxcombs, I'le teach you more manners.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Murder, murder.
sp.stage: Ex. They beat Landlord and Surgeon off o'th' Stage; Andenter Ladiſlaus and Paulina.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: See our Lords.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: And is it thus? come Theodore, my Sword.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Oh heavens, what is't I hear?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Come Sir, I know they'r wrong'd, by the fond talking world: they'r conſtant, generous, they'r Angels, Angel's, not a pound o' fleſh about 'um Sir; and doth it ſting thy ſoul? crawl, crawl about aſide his heart (thou Serpent jealouſie) until he foames with poyſon.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Heavens! I fear ſomething is ſtrangely amiſs with aſide with the young Duke, he hath talk't all day at this diſtracted rate. What ſhould the reaſon be? ſome ſecret ſorrow ſets heavy on him; but I'le take no notice. Come Theodore.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: My Lord, upon my knees—

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: No more, I'm wrong'd, abus'd, by my falſe friends,
And I will in, and dye in their defence,
Since they have loſt their guard of innocence:
If in a cauſe ſo bad my blood is ſpilt,
I have revenge by adding to their guilt▪
My noble Lord farewel, a thouſand bleſſings
Crown your ſweet youth; and when you ſee the Prince,
Do me the right t' inform him of my ſtory,
And recommend me to his noble thoughts;
Tell him the dying Duke o' Curland begs
A place, a Monument in his fair ſoul;
And ſo heaven bleſs you both.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: Oh! oh, I faint.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Now Theodore—
Farewel to thee, if I ne're ſee thee more,
Here take theſe Jewels, they are all I have
At preſent, to reward thy love and faithfulneſs;
And now dear Theodore, when the day is done;
And with it me, ſeek out my lifeleſs carcaſs
Among the dead, and give it a private Monument:
Let not my Princeſſes inſulting eye,
Find out where injured Curland's aſhes lie;
Leſt ſhe in ſcorn ſhould viſit him, and there
Profane my Tombe with a diſſembled tear.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: My Lord, be ſure I ſhall do this and more,
Ten thouſand times, if I'm not dead before.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: Ha, is he gone? and hath he left me thus?
Ne're was falſe Lady ſo belov'd as ſhe,
Nor any ſo unfortunate as me!
But ſee he is not gone, there there he ſtands,
Come here my kindeſt Lord, and kiſs me once,
But once before I die, for I am going
VVhere poor Paulina 'l trouble you no more.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Oh heavens! her grief miſlayes her noble reaſon, what ſhall we do

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I'le run and kill the Villain.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: Alexey ſee what ſhadow's that?
Is't not a Coffin? 'tis; come lock me in,
I know not whether I am dead or no,
But if I am not, I would feign be ſo.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Oh, I ſhall run my ſword into my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: And I ſhall break my heart.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: Sirs, lead me in.
VVell, ſince th'art gone, brave Ladiſlaus adieu,
I'de not have dealt thus cruelly by you;
But I forgive thee, and when no one's by,
I'le pray for thee, then fetch a groan and dye.

div.head: The Fourth ACT.
div.stage: Enter Oſſolinsky, Caſſonoſsky, Lubomirsky: After, ſhouts and acclamations without.
The Scene an open field covered with Tents.

sp.speaker: Oſſo. Caſſo.
sp.l: ALl's our own, victory, victory.
Come, for the plunder of the Princeſs Tent.

sp.speaker: Lub.
sp.p: But ſee Prince Radzevile, Commander of the Tranſilvanian horſe; what news from the dead? did not I ſee thee fall under thy horſe feet?

sp.speaker: Caſſo.
sp.l: Come, for the plunder of the Tent, brave Prince.

sp.speaker: Oſſo.
sp.l: Move ſlow Devils.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Never did ſuch a gale of fortune blow, I'le ſail in tides of blood up to their Tents, and take the Duke o' Curlands Miſtreſs priſoner, carry her to Moſcow, and keep her captive till Poland ranſomes her with Curlands blood; follow brave men.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Go, 'tis in vain to hinder thee
When honour calls, nor will I ſtop thee now,
Although he fights, he knows not where, nor how.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Muſt we not only fight with men, but Devils? Radzevile Commander of the Tranſilvanian horſe, who fell by my ſword, is mounted afreſh, hath broke through all our Troops, and Stands o' Pikes, and flies like lightning to the Princes Tent, and doth greater things, now dead, then living. Purſue the Warlike Ghoſt; all, all to the Princes Tent—But ſee whole Troops of flame; (A flame flaſhes through the Tents) a thouſand fiery Spears pierce every way, and a bright Cloud of fire breaks from the Town; what ſhould it mean?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: My Lord, to the Princes Tent, or ſhe is loſt.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Teach me my duty you ſlave;
What meanes this flame?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p:
It is ſome valiant ſtranger, but who I know not, that hath flown about juſt like a Fire-ſhip in Seas of blood to grapple with whole Fleets; and ſeeing the enemy flow all in Tides up to the Princes Tent, hath
ſet the Tents and all the Town on fire; and here with five hundred reſolute Cavalry he comes to force his paſſage.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Brave men, I'le lead the way to glory; all, all to th' Princes Tent.
sp.stage: Enter Ladiſlaus, Theodore, and followers with Flambaux in their hands.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Come valiant men, let's give 'um brave diverſion,
Lets ſet their Tents afloat in blood and flames,
And fill the Air with Clouds of humane aſhes;
Set all on fire, the Town, the Tents, the Temple;
Spare not the very houſes of Religion.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Brave Prince, how generous thy actions are!
Unſeen he changes all the Scenes of warr,
And with a noble ſcorn he fights for them
Who both his courage and his love contemn;
Theſe Glories muſt at laſt themſelves betray,
And through all gloomy Clouds muſt pierce a way.
sp.stage: The Scene is chang'd to the Princeſſes Pavilion; A noiſe of arms, The women ſhrieke within: And enter Hypolita, Emilia, Franciſca running.

sp.speaker: Hyp. Em. Fran.
sp.p: Murder, murder, the Princeſs will be murdered.
sp.stage: Enter Sharnofsky defending the Princeſs, purſued by Demetrius, Oſſolinsky, Caſſonoſsky, Lubomirsky, Battiſta, and Guard; the Women run about ſhrieking and crying murder.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Stand by Sharnofsky, I'le defend my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Madam, for heavens ſake do not deprive me in the laſt moment of my life, of that which I have liv'd and fought for all this while;
sp.l: For if without defending you I'me ſlain,
I looſe my honour, and I die in vain.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That honour you ſhall have, but not alone,
Nor rob my courage Sir, to crown your own.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Oh! whether doth ſhe ruſh? for ſhame ye cowards ſet not your ſwords againſt a Ladies breaſt, your Princeſs too: ſhe bleeds; you ſaucy Villains, y'ave wounded a Divinity, th' Americans would have kneeled and prayed to; ye Powers, what are ye all aſleep above the Clouds? if ye are, lend me your thunder: oh! ſhe's loſt.

sp.speaker: Oſſo.
sp.p: You are my priſoner Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: You Princeſs, are mine.

sp.speaker: Caſſo.
sp.p: So now ſhall I have a full draught of revenge.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p:
Now know fond Poles, I have deluded you; I am not Radzevile, but Demetrius, a Prince o' the Imperial houſe of Muſcovy; a mortal,
an eternal enemy to you all; I come to ſearch your General, the Duke of Curland, who like a treacherous Pole, after I had took him priſoner, ſhew'd him kindneſs, hath ſtole my Princeſs, and I'le enſlave his, and the next time I come, enſlave you all: And now ſtand by me valiant Tranſilvanians, I'le give you all a hundred crowns a man.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Oh! the good heavens, he betrayes himſelf.

sp.speaker: Oſſo. Caſſo. Lub.
sp.p: Ha! what ſaith Radzevile?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: This is diſtraction.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Muſt I be carried then a ſlave to Moſcow?

sp.speaker: Hyp. Em. Fran.
sp.p: Oh, the Princeſs! oh, this Ruſſian ſlave!

sp.speaker: Oſſo. Caſſo. Lub.
sp.p: He's mad, he raves.

sp.speaker: Caſſo.
sp.p: Hold Sir, cleave the Rebels head, ſlaves.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Heaven! what ſtupid Lethargy hath ſeiz'd thee? aſſiſt, unbind me, or elſe ſtrike me dead, rather then torture me with ſuch a ſight.

sp.speaker: Oſſo. Caſſo. Lub.
sp.p: Hold Rebel, Villain.

sp.speaker: Oſſo.
sp.p: My Lords, command all your men, Horſe and Foot, to ſurround the Tranſilvanian Troops, and make 'um fling down their Arms, or dye.

sp.speaker: Lub.
sp.p: Let all the Coſſacques wheele.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Fire, give fire; a hundred of you ſtay, and guard the priſoners.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Oh! the unruly fire that governs thee, Where will it lead thee?

sp.speaker: Caſſo.
sp.p: Now to guard the Priſoners ſhall be my work:

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: How am I made the ſport and ſcorn of Fortune, abus'd by Curland, trampled on by ſlaves; and now led bound to follow the Triumphant Chariot of Scarlet perjury?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: My ſoul is torn with grief and rage.

sp.speaker: Caſſo.
sp.p: Come then, I'le eaſe you both; alas I pity you; but chiefly you, good Princeſs: your kind Father I thank him eas'd me of many a burthen ſome employment; and I in gratitude will eaſe your ſhoulders of ſuch a weighty head laden with ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Hyp. Em. Fran.
sp.p: Oh bloody Villain!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Inſolent ſlave; dares ſuch a thing as thee threaten a Princeſs life?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Barbarous Dogg, bring me but to him, I le kick his dirty ſoul out of his body.

sp.speaker: Caſſo.
sp.p: I'le ſnap thy ſaucy head from off thy ſhoulders firſt. Guards kill the priſoners, I'le not allow the formality of praying; and he that asks what Orders I have for it, let 'um know, I wear my Orders by my ſide; this is my Cardinal, Senate, and my King, off with their heads, his crooked Majeſty commands it.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Thou Monſter of mankind, haſt thou no ſenſe of pity or humanity, nor of thy own, nor of thy Countries honor, which ſuch a horrid act will render infamous to all the world? here quench thy barbarous thirſt of blood with mine, open all my veins, take my life, my fortune, honour, all I have, but ſpare, oh ſpare the Daughter of thy King.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No more my Lord, ſwell not the Villains pride by falling proſtrate to it; Quick Hypolita, give me a Ponyard.

sp.speaker: Caſſo.
sp.p: Fetch a Wrack, an Engine, I'le torter him to death: But ha! more ſport, de'e come to put affronts upon the Kingdoms.
sp.stage: (Enter Oſſolimsky and Guard, with Demetrius, and Battiſta bound.

sp.speaker: Oſſo.
sp.p: In the face of the whole Army Sir, Ile cool your fiery inſolence.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Yes, murder me you ſlaves,
I do deſerve this puniſhment, and more,
That my revenge ſhould be ſo low and poor;
I ought t' have ſet it at no lower rate
Then the whole ruine of your Poliſh State,
All of you hudled in one common doom,
Curland the Cipher to make up the ſum.

sp.speaker: Caſſo.
sp.l: Tame the proud Rebel; Guards, off with his head.

sp.speaker: Oſſo.
sp.l: Hold, ſtrike who dares, till I give the command!

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Come Villains, level me right againſt the Clouds,
And then give fire, diſcharge my flaming ſoul
Againſt ſuch ſaucy Deſtinies as thoſe
As dare thus baſely of my life diſpoſe;
Then from the Clouds rebounding I will fall,
And like a clap of thunder tear you all.

sp.speaker: Oſſo.
sp.l: VVell then Sir, ſince your ſpirit is ſo high,
Your head ſhall be as lofty by and by,
Yes, you'r exalted thoughts ſhall have their due,
Your head ſhall ſtand in both the Armies view.

sp.speaker: Caſſo.
sp.l: Guards, are you aſleep? cleave all their heads at once.

sp.speaker: Oſſo. Caſſo.
sp.l: Strike.
sp.stage: All the Women give a ſhriek, and at that inſtant enter Lubomirsky running.

sp.speaker: Lub.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Oſſo. Caſſo.
sp.l: Count Lubomirsky, the news?

sp.speaker: Lub.
sp.l:
All's loſt; I am in ſuch a confuſion I cannot ſpeak, ſome Devil
in humane ſhape hath quite turn'd all the fortune of the day, hath fir'd the Town, the Tents, and here he's coming on waves of blood and flame.

sp.speaker: Laſſo.
sp.l: Hell take thee for thy news; where is this Devil?

sp.speaker: Caſſo. Oſſo.
sp.l: The Gurads retire; ſtand Villains, or you die.

sp.speaker: Lub.
sp.l: Stand, cowardly ſlaves.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Is Fortune penitent? Battiſta looſe me.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: I am bound too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Are your teeth bound too, Sir?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.l: Ha! is the Scale a turning?
A thouſand crowns but for one hand looſe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Deliverance ſwift like lightning! Heaven, I thank thee.
sp.stage: Enter Ladiſlaus driving the Gaurds before him, followed by Theodore, and Cavaliers.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Stay flying Cowards; diſparage not my ſword,
Let it be ſaid at leaſt I fought with men.

sp.speaker: Oſſo. Caſſo. Lub.
sp.l: We are loſt.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And muſt I ſtand to be a thing of pity,
To receive the charity of this mans ſword?

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.l: I bluſh at our own chaines, and this mans glory.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Secure the Lords, Madam, the Scene is chang'd,
You'r all at liberty;
And now my next great deed ſhall be
To ſet my heart at liberty from thee.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: My noble Lord,
Thus through the field with unſeen triumphs flies,
As ſouls make their Entradoes in the skies;
Sure Heaven ſome mighty glory hath deſign'd,
At laſt to crown ſuch an Illuſtrious mind.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What Prodigy's this?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: 'Tis your Angel, Madam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A thouſand Crowns to know him.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.l: A Warlike Fantome.
By heaven created for this exigence.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: His haughty Valour hath affronted me,
I • le out and kill him for his inſolence,
And when he's dead, I'le hug him for his bravery.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: To arms again; thus doth his active ſoul
Leap from one danger to another;
Here we deſtroy, and there we ſave,
As Veſſels toſt from Wave to Wave.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.l: Let's out, and help to reap this glorious Harveſt;
But hark, a loud Volley of Martial ſhouts.

sp.speaker: All within.
sp.l: Long live Juliana, our Queen.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.l: Bleſt noiſe; your name is bandied in the Clouds,
There's a victorious Tempeſt in the Aire,
And ſee a thouſand lights approach the Tent.

sp.speaker: Caſſo.
sp.l: Oh curſed ſight! and curſed noiſe.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Now Madam, all's our own; your enemies have all flung down their arms, ſome come to crave your pardon, others flie in multitudes to the Cardinals Tent; the Cardinal in tranſports of rage for his misfortune, confeſt his horrid villanies, and fled: I ſent an Officer to conduct him to a private Grotto in a neighbouring Grove, pretendingly for his ſecurity; In the interim the croudes rifled his Tent, and found the Crown conceal'd, and here they'r coming ſailing along with ſhouts and acclamations, reſolving to repoſe it on your brow.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The weight's too great for me.

sp.speaker: All within.
sp.l: Secure the diſtracted State.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: The people grow impatient.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I'le ſacrifice my ſelf t'appeaſe the croudes;
Heavens! never was ſuch a turn of fortune known,
From a Scaffold to a Throne,
In one moment to be ſeen,
A dying Captive and a Queen.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: So now my good Lords you may be all at leaſure for holy contemplations:

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.l: Guards, ſee eſpecially
To that malicious Count.

sp.speaker: Caſſo.
sp.l: I know your kindneſs, I need not go to an Aſtrologer to know my doom: What a long neck ſhall I have when my head's ſet upon a Pole on one of the City Gates.

sp.speaker: Oſſo. Lub.
sp.l: This is the giddineſs of Fortune.
sp.stage: Lead away with Guard as priſoners.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: This way the Spirit went, and as it walk't I ſaw a kind of ſhape reſembling Curland.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: My Lord, your fancy in the heat of paſſion forges a thouſand Images.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: If 'twas his Ghoſt, I'le find out his abode; let it be Aire, Earth, or Fire.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: If it walks any where, 'tis there amongſt the Queens tryumphant Train

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I hear 'um ſhout, I'le amongſt 'um.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Hold Sir, pray let 'um not diſcover you for fear the Poles revenge th' affront you did their Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Then I'le revenge th' affront the Poles did me.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Heavens! what a task have I? It is the ſame,
To bridle a tempeſt, or to ſteer a flame.
sp.stage: Enter the Cardinal conducted by an Officer. The Scene a hollow Rock in a Grove.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Heaven! have mercy! whither doſt thou lead me?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: I was commanded to conduct you hither;
The Count will come to you here, and bring the news.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: He is a worthy friend.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: 'Tis dark and private,
Here you may lie with ſafety.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Thus in a moment is my Sun gone down.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: My Lord, convey your ſelf away with ſpeed, All's loſt; your men are fled, your Tent is plunder'd; the Princeſs Crown'd, and all your friends betray you; my Lord Grand Marſhal's • oming with a Guard from the Queen to ſecure you.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Then there's no truſt in man.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: This way Sir; haſten.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Hold Sir, not ſo faſt.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Art thou ſet here to betray me too?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: To guard you Sir.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: To guard me as a Victim for Sacrifice; I am at laſt outwitted in Villany.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Oh heavens! Sir, you'r loſt,
The Queen approaches; heark the dreadful ſhouts,
A thouſand ſtreaming lights flow all this way.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: And let 'um come, I have a friend in private will not betray me.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A poiſoned Handkerchief I fear.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: The little winding-ſheet of all my glories;
Ah! had I ſtudied but as much to gain
Heaven, as this world, I had not ſweat in vain:
Inſtead of horrours that purſue me now,
Immortal Crowns had waited for my brow;
But my amazing miſeries now are
Beyond the aid of Penitence and Prayer:
To my own Idols I too long did bow,
To put that fawning cheat on heaven now;
For he hath my Religion underſtood
To be but craft, and my devotion blood.
My heaven was t'aſcend the Papal Throne,
Where to ſave others ſouls, I've loſt my own.
And now, alas! 'twere folly to deny
My ſelf the pleaſure to deſpair and die.
May all great men learn by my wretched Fate,
Never to ſtake their ſouls at games of State;
For though a while perhaps they ſeem to win,
They'l find at laſt there is no cheat like ſin.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: He's gone; irrecoverably gone; his great ſouls fled,
And ſee a thouſand lights uſher the Queen;
She comes to ſee her mighty enemy
sp.stage: The Scene ſhuts upon the Card. &c.
sp.l: Lye a cold Statue proſtrate at her feet.
sp.stage: Enter Juliana Crown'd, Hypolita, Emilia, Franciſca, Sharnofsky, Colimsky, and Guards, at one end of the Theater, Paulina as mixt with the crowd.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Long live Juliana Queen of Poland.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My Lords, I thank you for all this great honour.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: I've ſtole from Count Alexey and Joanna,
To ſeek my Lord, and I'me afraid to find him,
Or with my Rival here, or with the dead;
If here I find him, I'm reſolv'd he dyes,
Only to ſpoil the tryumphs of her eyes;
But ſee, my ſervants come, I'le get away.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Heavens! where is ſhe wander'd; and how came we to loſe her?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: What do'ſt thou do crowding in here? idle body, come help us to look our Maſter.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I look your Maſter, go hang your ſelf with your Maſter.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What murmurings that?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: See Guards, what means that noiſe?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: No Raſcals, I remember your Megrim, your Snuſh, and your Muſtard; I'le make you pay dear for that Muſtard, it ſhall be coſtly Muſtard.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Oh! is it you Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Guards keep off the Rabble; take that rude fellow, clap him neck and heels.

sp.speaker: Ale. Jo.
sp.p: Begone, quick, quick, and leave the Rogue i'th' Bilboes.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Oh, good your Honour, I beſeech your ſweet Honour.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sirrah, what's your buſineſs here?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Nothing an't like your honour, but a couple of idle quarrelſome Raſcals that lie at my houſe, ha' loſt their Maſter, and they'd make me look for their Maſter; Now if they ha' loſt their Maſter, I'm not bound to make good their Maſter by no Law in Poland; I refer it to your Honour.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Get you about your buſineſs Sirrah, and make no references to me.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I thank your Honour, I believe your Honour knows me, don't you remember where you lay when your Honour kept the fat Lady, the Lady Clumsky? you could make references to her for all your pride.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: B • gone Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I thought I ſhould put you in mind of a reference; I've done an't like your Honour.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Now my Lords, what news of the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nigh to this part of the field is the Grotto where I commanded him to be conveigh'd, and ſee the Officer I ſent to guard him.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: My Lord the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Oſſo.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: Dead.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Dead.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: He lies ſo near, Torches may ſhew him you.
sp.stage: The Scene is drawn, the Cardinal preſented dead in a Grotto, a Gentleman waiting by him.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Oh, bominable! kild? and is the Councel o' Trent, and Pope Paul come to this? thou muſt know honeſt Guard I'm a merry man, and I us'd to viſit this good man's back Cellar o' Rheniſh, and then I call'd it the Council o' Trent, and there was a great Tun, great Grandfather, or Goſſip at leaſt to the great Tun o' Heydelburgh, and that I us'd to call Pope Paul the third, and there did the Beef-eaters o' the Guard and I—

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Beef-eaters you Raſcal!

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Sit in Councel about the good o' Chriſtendom, till at parting we did our reverences to Pope Paul, fall down and kiſs his great Toe, the Spigot, and let the heavenly Benediction drop into our mouthes.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: You'd have my Halbeard drop into your mouthes, would you Beef-eater, you ſaucy Cur?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A mournful ſpectacle; how died the Cardinal?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Proudly as he liv'd; he would not ſtoop to pray,
Or if he pray'd, 'twas ſo, as he would ſeem
He expected heaven ſhould firſt pray to him;
He gave up's glory, but with ſuch a pride,
He ſcorn'd to keep it, ſince he was deny'd;
And though with death he found ſome little ſtrife,
Rather then ask, he would reſign his life.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: What a wicked fellow was this? oh, ſye upon him! not ſay his Prayers when he died! how doth he ever think to come to good; my Lord, he was as arrant a—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Guard—

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I ha' done, an't like your Honour.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Sirrah, I could find in my heart to Beef-eat you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
I'm ſorry for his ſoul, but heaven's merciful! ah! had this great
mans piety been equal to's wiſdom, and his many other Noble Vertue he had been a man too glorious.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Nay truly, he had as good a Study of Books I'le ſay for that him, good old Authours, Sack and Claret, Rheniſh and old Hock; come ſaid I to the Library keeper, tap me St. Gregory, or that good old Father a tilt that looks like St. George a Horſe back; take his Nag by the Spigot, and give our brains a leap, ſaid I.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Thou haſt a mind to be laid by th' heels with thy Pope Paul.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I ha' done honeſt Guard.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.l: He was too ſelf admiring, and conceited
The Church and we did but his wiſdom owe
All honours Rome or Poland could beſtow.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: He was ſomething ſelf-conceited indeed, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: He had a ſoaring ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: Reaching wiſdom.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Unſatiably ambitious, and inexorable.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: He was a notable man.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No more my Lords; what he hath done, he's gone to anſwer for; then for the reverence we owe Religion, let him be Interr'd with decency.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: And for the reverence I owe burnt Claret, I'le be at's Funeral.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Now all the Storms are paſt, the Winds are down,
The Waves tranſport me gently to a Crown:
Kind heaven ſmiles, and I am got above
All other Tempeſts but the World and Love:
And now I'le ſeek Religions flowry ſhore,
And be expos'd to all theſe ſtorms no more.
My Lords attend me, and you all ſhall know
How I'le my perſon, and the Crown beſtow.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Well, I ſwear this is a delicate woman, I'de give all I'am worth in the world I were a young Prince for her ſake, I'de ſo jumble her and tumble her, I'de ſet her upon her head, and her heels, and kiſs this end, and that end, and all in an honeſt way too.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Theſe words are of dubious and myſterious ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.p: To a Cloyſter I fear.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: My Lords prevail with her,
I can aſſure you ſhe deſigns a Cloyſter.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Let's attend her to the Palace, and then meet in Councel.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p:
Well, it's a lovely Creature; I love her ſo well, I could be contented to be a little Shock • or her ſake, that I might lye in het lap, lick her lips, and be ſtroak't, but hang't it would but puff me up, I ſhould be too proud and ſelf-conceited: But here's a devilliſh fall in my
wiſhes, now I think on't, from a Prince to a Puppy-Dog, but love is humble. Well now, there's a Harveſt a coming, a Coronation; oh, what a crop of Dollars will I reap for my windows, and Belcony: I'le have a Rix Dollar for every quarry in my window, and a hundred for my Belcony; that is to ſay, fifty for my Bell, and fifty for my Coney.
sp.l: In all I'le have in currant Poliſh money,
A hundred Rix Dollers for my Bell-coney.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Heavens! I've loſt him, whither is he wander'd?
What new Fury hath tranſported him?
But ha! the glittering of a naked Sword;
A perſon tall, and of my Princes ſtature,
Walking about, and hark I hear a voice!

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: Heavens! I walk about here in the dark,
And hear the labours of departing ſouls;
A thouſand aiery formes flie round about me,
And fan me into cold and dewey ſweats:
Oh! if my Lord be dead, would I were with him.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: The place is inchaunted.
sp.stage: Enter Demetrius with his naked ſword.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: There the dying voice fainted away, by that old wall—no lyar, that was an eccho.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: My Prince, ſome frightful Apparition leads him about.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: What art thou that uſurp'ſt the ſacred name of my divinity?
Speak, or I'le turn a Ghoſt as thin as thee,
And torture thee.—

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Heark, the Guards are near, I will avoid 'um, and go fetch a Torch, and ſeek my Lord among the dead, in thoſe pale Groves he is unkindly wander'd, t'avoid his poor Paulina.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Heark, the voice cries Paulina.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Paulina ſtill; what faucy Spirit mocks me with that name? could I but find thee, I'de tear thy aerial body into Atomes; and I'le have light, or I'le fire this Grove, I, & ſet thee on a Rack of flame to make thee confeſs, who, and what thou art? and a light comes from behind that wall, a youth with a Torch, I'le run and fetch it.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: He's grown diſtracted, I muſt ſpeak to him Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: And doſt appear at laſt!

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: 'Tis I; Battiſta Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I know I might have kil'd thee ſo; I'm led about with voices, groans, illuſions; fetch me that Torch.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: A fair and lovely youth walking among the dead; ſure 'tis ſome Spectre.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Fetch me that Torch!
sp.stage: Joanna and Alexey run over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: There ſhe is all alone walking with a Torch.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Under that Tree.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I ſee her, let's run, let's run to her?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Hark, a conſort of voices.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Let's leave this diſmal place? there's a Cabal of melancholly Spirits that haunt it; ſee two flying ſhapes come towards this youth.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I think the dead hold here their Rendeſvouze; heark, there are more come from yonder Grove? I'm tortur'd, plagu'd; fetch me the Torch I ſay?
sp.stage: Bat. Ex. and enter Lad. and Theo.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Now Theodore, preſs me no more,
I now renounce her, and her Sex for ever.
And now I've ſteer'd her ſafely to a Throne,
I'le leave her in her Ports, and to my own,
From whence the war ſhe hath on me begun,
Shall now on all the world be carried on;
And captive Monarches ſhall of her complain,
And curſe my injuries and her diſdain,
Whil'ſt I ſhall ſtill by blood and ſlaughter prove
The ſcorn and hate I bear to her, and love.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ho! ſtand, what are you? Battiſta, come with a Torch!

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Heark, the Perdues call to the Guard; I'le in my Chariot to Town; do you ride before, Theodore, and get Poſt-horſes ready this night, I'le onward on my way to Curland.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: To Curland! Ye Powers, ſtand, ſtand, come with the Torch you ſlave.
sp.stage: Enter Battiſta running, and layes hold on Dem.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Sir, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I ſee a Chariot, Villain ſtand by or I'le kill thee.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Are you diſtracted Sir? yonder's your Princeſs; I've overheard their talk.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Yonder's Curlands Chariot, and the ſlave holds me.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Ha! I ſee a Chariot, I'le after it, do you go to your Princeſs: here, here Sir.
sp.stage: Enter Paulina, Joanna, Alexcy with a Torch.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: Hark, I hear a voice.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: It is the Guards.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Here Sir, by all that's good, this is your Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: After the Chariot then, flie; Sir, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: The Guards call to us, out with the Torch Alex.

sp.speaker: Paul. Jo.
sp.l: Run, run; murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Flie Madam, I'le make good your retreat.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Curſe on my folly, I've loſt 'um in the dark.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: Ha, loſt them and the Chariot both? curſe on this raſhneſs; here, here they flee.
sp.stage: Both run confuſedly croſſing each other, and know not which way to take.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Here, here's a path.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: I ſee the Chariot going ſtraight to Town.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I ſee the ſhape flying on the wind before me.

div.head: The Laſt ACT.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: WIth much ado I've overtaken the Chariot, and I'm ſo out of breath I cannot ſpeak; ha, ſtop't her, by that Belcony! this is our Lodging, it is, and ſee the perſons coming out of the houſe with a light, where do they go, I'le watch 'um.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Oh! I am faint with running, and the fright; where's Alexey?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: He ſtay'd behind to guard us, but ſee he hath been here before us.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, the Duke is newly alighted at the door, and on ſome news I know not what it is; He's gone ſtraight to the Palace.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Heavens! what ſhould it be?

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.p: They talk the Queen is gone into a Cloyſter, ſome ſay to marry.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Oh! what comes into my head? Joanna ſlip to my Chamber, and get a Feather and a better Perriwig, and follow the Duke with all the ſpeed you can.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: I run, I run.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: 'Twas here they came; this was the houſe I'm ſure: ho, ho, the houſe!

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Ha! my Landlord, what, am I at home?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: You Rogue, you Dog, I'le kill you Sirrah, I • le murder you; would not you tell me this before.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Hold, come along with me quickly, ſhew me all your rooms, here's a Princeſs lodges here.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Don't tell me o' Princeſſes? the Rogue hath undone me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Sirrah, come along, or I'le ſend your Soul before me.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Sirrah, hold your prating, I've loſt more then thee and all thy generation are worth; I've loſt five thouſand Crowns, and I'le ſtop it out of his wages, I'le not pay one of 'um a farthing. But what will that do? that's ſome fifty Dollars; what's that to five thouſand Crowns? undone, undone.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Dog, I'le ſet fire on's houſe.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Will you ſo Sirrah? a brave amends for my loſs; but Sirrah, I'le keep you faſt enough for that, go quickly boy, run and fetch a Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: A Conſtable, Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Murder, murder; ho! there Sirrah, come back again, I ſhall be kil'd: you bloudy Rogue, will you murder me?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Good Sir, don't kill my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Hold him whil'ſt I go run and fetch a Conſtable and ſecure his Cloakbag, and then I muſt to the Palace after this baſe cheating Duke. I've a pack of brave Lodgers: here's one young blade, that I'm much miſtaken if he or his man be n't a Whore; and the Duke's run away and paid me no Rent; and this vapouring Jack would kill me, and then ſet fire on my houſe; brave doings, is't not? but I'le feage you all.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What Duke's that?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: The Duke o' Curland's an't pleaſe you Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Curland, where, where, quickly ſlave.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I chanc't to ſpy him, and came and told my Maſter, and for this he would ha' kill'd me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Where I ſay, Villain?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, he is juſt gone to the Palace; a young Gentleman that lodges here brought a Courtier that told him the Queen was to be married to night, and they are all run to the Palace together.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I'le make one o' the company, his ſoul ſhall dance Levoltoes in the Aire at the Queens wedding.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: VVell, I was a fool he did not let this Gentleman kill my Maſter, or fire his houſe, I would he had,—teach him to be labour me for my good will.
sp.stage: Enter Ladiſlaus, Paulina, Joanna dreſt like a Courtier, Alexey, Theodore, at a diſtance—Battiſta. The Scene a Palace to the Street.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: So, I have overtaken 'um,
And here's ſome great myſterious thing in hand,
The Duke hath ſome deſign about the Crown.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Knock at the Gate Theodore.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p:
Indeed my Lord, this Courtier is miſtaken; all ſay poſitively
the Queen's reſolv'd t'reſign the Crown, and go into a Cloyſter, and that ſhe ſpends this night among her Prieſts, and women in devotion to prepare for it; and now all the Lords of the Council are gone in to diſſwade her.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Knock when I bid you.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Come good my Lord, do not expoſe your ſelf to ſo much danger; the Gentleman's miſinform'd.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Perhaps ſo Sir, I only told you what my ſiſter, who is a Maid of Honour to the Queen, told me.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Your Siſter!

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: My Lord, let it be true or falſe, I am reſolv'd to be conceal'd no longer:
sp.l: Thus to the ſinful world revenge divine,
And Heaven ſtands behind the Clouds awhile,
And let's deluded man himſelf beguile;
And ſeems as if his Law he did not own,
But with brave ſcorn to let the World alone,
Till man grown impudent, begins to play
His Villanies in open Scenes of day;
Then ſtrikes, ſtrikes home, and then his arm doth fall
With ſuch a weight, one blow may ſerve for all:
Thus my revenge I do a while retain,
That when I ſtrike, I may not ſtrike in vain.
Why doſt not knock, Theodore?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I do my Lord, and none will anſwer within, h • there, open the Gate!

sp.speaker: Porter within
sp.p: What would you have there? here can none come in.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Give the fellow forty crowns.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Here are perſons o' great quality, you ſhall have forty crowns to open the Gate.

sp.speaker: Porter within.
sp.p: Bear back there, Guard keep off the crowd.

sp.speaker: People within.
sp.p: Oh, pray Mr. Porter.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: I dread th'event, I wiſh I had not done this.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Take notice Sir, if any miſchief befalls my Lord, you and your Dukes lives ſhall anſwer for it.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Do you threaten Sir—Alexey.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.p: I hear the ſlave, let him have a care I don't cut his throat, and his Maſters the worthy Duke.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: I'le after you all to ſee the meaning o' this.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p:
Now I warrant ſhall I ha' much ado to get into the Gate after this cheating Knave the Duke, I muſt ſpeak 'um fair; Porter: honeſt
old Crony, friend and fellow Souldier in the Wars o' Bacchus, open the door, my drunken Bulley.

sp.speaker: Porter within
sp.p: What ſaucy fellow's that? get you from the Gate, Sirrah, or the Guard ſhall lay you by the heels.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Oh, the Rogue, he pretends not to know me, he knows me well enough; why honeſt Bulley Cerberus, Corporal-turnkey, Squire o' the houſe, 'Nointer o' Page-bums, Engineer General o' double Locks, Spring-locks, Pad-locks, and Mouſe-traps, open the Placket o' the houſe, call'd the Wicket, and let's in boy. Doſt not remember the Council o' Trent, and Pope Paul the third.

sp.speaker: Porter within.
sp.p: Prating Raſcal! you 've a mind to be laid by th' heels.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Oth' cunning Raſcal! he thinks I ha' company with me now, he's as cunning! but here comes my ſlaves, what ha' you ſet fire on my houſe yet?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How now, the Gate barr'd? open the door here.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Nay, if I can't get in, I believe you'l hardly get in, for all your brave Cloakbag.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Open the door, or I'le ſet fire on't.

sp.speaker: Porter within
sp.p: De'e threaten Sirrah! Guard, out quickly, here's a Traytour threatens to fire the Palace Gate.

sp.speaker: Guard
sp.p: Bear back there, let's come out;

sp.speaker: People within.
sp.p: Oh, you crowd me.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: So, ſo, you have done finely, we ſhall have our brains knock't out; come, come, a ſpell quickly afore they come, I know the Rogues as well as if I were in the bottom of their bellies; come half a Doller or ſo—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Open the door fellow, thou ſhalt have fifty Dollars.

sp.speaker: Porter within
sp.p: If I do let you in, you ca'nt get into the Preſence—the Guard-rooms are all crowded; I let in a Gentleman juſt now, and he ſtands in the crow'd ſtill.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: The Rogue begins to be plyable.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Open the door I ſay, here's thy money.

sp.speaker: Porter within.
sp.p: Bear back there, keep off the crowds.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Now you can bear back with a pox to you, now you hear o' money; well, I ſee this money will make every thing bear back, and flie open.

sp.speaker: One within.
sp.p: Ah Mr. Porter, we'l give a Rix-Dollar, betwixt four of us.

sp.speaker: Porter within.
sp.p: A Rope between four of you.
sp.stage: Enter Juliana, Hypolita, Emilia, Franciſca, Colimsky, Sharnofsky, and a Prieſt.
The Scene a Room in the Palace; a Table with the Crown, Scepter, and Regalia at one end, and Beads, and Books at the other.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Well Madam, ſince we muſt deſpair t'obtain,
VVe'l ceaſe thoſe pray'rs, which we thus make in vain;
For to our ſorrow we confeſs it true,
This Kingdom hath not glory 'enough for you.
In thoſe Celeſtial Crowns you'l only find
Exalted glories equal to your mind:
VVe only beg you'l help the ſhrinking Throne,
And ſave ten thouſand ſouls beſides your own:
For, Madam, whatſoe're your Prieſts pretend,
You may by Crowns, to Crowns aſcend:
And Cells on Earth, will Cells in heaven find,
Large Crowns for mighty bounties are deſign'd.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.l: And Madam, I but one thing will implore,
That when you addreſs your ſelf to the Sacred Altarr
You'l pleaſe to recollect upon what ſcore,
You at thoſe Altars have ſtood once before.
VVhen Vows with Vows, Altars with Altars jars,
It ſeems to breed in heaven a civil warr;
It is not for the Duke I intercede,
I now in the behalf of Honour plead:
Though to the ſacred Church I freely bow,
No doubt they can abſolve you from your Vow;
Yet with the reverence to their power is due,
Methinks I would have Honour do it too:
In other worlds Devotion may have bliſs,
I'me ſure 'tis Honour that muſt ſave in this;
And generous Honour paſſes doom on none,
Till firſt their crimes are clearer than the Sun.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My Lords, on either ſide I've heard your pleas,
And very much reſent your kindneſſes:
But now my ſouls employ'd on things above,
Concerns of Empire, and much more of love.
As for the Duke I cannot cenſur'd be,
I quit not him, but he renounces me;
Nor for the Throne, I found it in diſtreſs,
And mildly leave it in the calmes of peace:
And now eternally I bid adieu
To Love, and Empire, to the Duke and you:
And here my Lords, I do your Crown reſtore,
And now retreat to what I was before.

sp.speaker: Confeſſor.
sp.l: Great Victory; you Saints above make room,
A mighty Spirit doth in tryumph come.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Hold Madam, e're you fall ſo great a weight,
And break in pieces our disjoynted State;
Rather then we will ruſh again once more
In the wild Chaos we were in before;
'Tis voted by us all, that you alone
Shall fix ſome perſon in our ſhaking Throne.
We ſwear Allegiance t' whomſoe're you chuſe,
Yea, and the death of him that ſhall refuſe:
'Tis all our votes.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: All, all.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: The truſt is high, and great, and needs many ſolemn thoughts, and you muſt give me ſome time to pauſe.

sp.speaker: Confeſſ.
sp.l: Madam, the better to compoſe your mind,
And fortifie your ſoul in theſe laſt conflicts
With earthly glory; pleaſe to reſt a while,
We'l uſe the devout Ars of holy Church.

div.stage: The Queen ſeats her ſelf in a Thone; the Ladies ſtand in order on her right hand, and the Lords on her left, whil'ſt a Chorus of voices ſing.

lg.l: How nobly heaven doth receive
what 're a pious mind
Is in Devotion pleas'd to give,
as if he Crowns reſign'd;
The ſacred Vaults with joy reſound.
The Altars all with Roſes Crownd,
And the poor Saint in tryumph brought
To offer up one holy thought.
And if to that ſuch honour's due,
What glorie's wait, (great Queen) for you▪
Chorus. And if to, &c.
If heaven thinks an humble bow
to him devoutly meant,
Then we whole Hecatombes beſtow
in one devout intent;
When Queens lay youth and glory by,
To ſeek out Crowns of chaſtity:
Some brighter Stars muſt ſure compound,
The Wreath wherewith her head is Crown'd:
For more then common Honour's due
To Royal Saints, Great Queen, like you:
Chorus. For more, &c,
Then bleſt be all my ſtorms of love,
(though they diſcourteous were)
That on our peaceful ſhore hath drove
a Saint, ſo Great, ſo Fair:
Now let the Boy with all his train
of griefs, go weeping back again;
Whil'ſt you ſet Sail before the wind,
And leave this floating world behind.
Till ſpooning gently on, and fair,
You turn an Angel unaware.
Chorus. Till ſpooning, &c.

sp.speaker: Confeſ.
sp.l: Now that your royal ſoul is flown • oft
Upon the wings of Divine Harmony;
We'l keep it there by holy repreſentation,
Firſt of the vaniſhing glories of the world,
Its ſplendid entrances, its ſhady Exits.
sp.stage: Enter two Queens followed by two Ghoſts, they paſs ſlowly over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Confeſ.
sp.l: Saw you thoſe Royal Shadows paſs the round
With all the charms of Power and beauty Crownd:
VVould not the glory which they did diſplay,
Make the world think none are ſo bleſt as they?
Alas, had they but look'd on either ſide,
They might have ſeen what would have damp't their pride:
Two pining Spirits that wer'e once as fair,
Shewing with ſighs where they muſt all repair:
Such are th' unſeen ſhadows that attend
All earthly glory, and in thoſe they end.
Now the next thing that we ſhall repreſent,
Is chaſt Devotion, recluſe Piety,
It's humble entrances, its glorious Exits.
sp.stage: Enter two Nuns clad in white, follow'd by two Angels Crown'd, They paſs as the former.

sp.speaker: Confeſ.
sp.l: Saw you thoſe Virgins paſs in holy ſtate?
Obſerve how Angels on their Triumphs wait:
Their Souls are as their Beauties fair and bright;
Their thoughts are as their garments pure and white:
Their dreams are Viſions, and their breath is Pray'r;
They'r faſted into Spirits thin as Aire;
Nor can you them from holy Angels know,
Since theſe are Nuns above, and they below.
And now you in a ſolemn dance ſhall ſee,
How all theſe move to Divine Harmony;
Confus'dly mixt each in their ſeveral States,
VValking around the changes of their Fates;
The world is a great dance in which we find
The good and bad have various turns aſſign'd;
But when th' have ended the great Maſquerade,
One goes to glory, to'ther to a Shade.

sp.speaker: Colim.
sp.l: VVhat tumults that?

sp.speaker: 2 Gentle.
sp.p: My Lords, here is a perſon of unknown quality deſires admiſſion; by's habit we conjecture 'tis the ſame that fought to day ith' head of all our Troops, and ſav'd the Count and Princeſs in the field.

sp.speaker: Oſſo.
sp.l: He's highly welcome; let him have admiſſion.
sp.stage: Enter Ladiſlaus diſguis'd, followed by Paulina, Joanna, Alexey, Theodore, at a diſtance, Battiſta, all the Lords bow to Lad.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: It ſeems the Bridal Maſque is done.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: So, I ha' crowded in among the reſt,
To ſee th' event of this myſterious buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I have conſiderd on't, my Lord Sharnofsky, heaven and your own merits deſign you for the Crown.
sp.stage: She takes the Crown off the Table, and preſents it to Shar. who ſeems to refuſe it, and the Lords to conſtrain him.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Ye Powers!

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: VVhat Tragedies will here be ſtreight?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: She's falſe indeed.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.l: Great Madam.

sp.speaker: Lords.
sp.l:
Kneel, and receive the Crown.
Shar. kneels

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: aſide Ha! is it ſo?
Then now I ſee, I have not been deceiv'd,
Sharnofsky, as thy glory, ſo thy fate,
Is very near, and thus ſuccesful villany;
Heaven let's it to the top of glory come,
Then (draws) thus ſtrikes it dead with unexpected doom.
sp.p: Sharnofsky draw, there's one obſtruction more lies in your way to all your glories; the Duke o' Curlands Sword.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: The Duke of Curland!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Ye Powers! the Dukel I faint Hypolita, Emilia hold me?

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Help the Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.l: The Duke of Curlands Sword; and can that Sword
Be ſet againſt my breaſt? for what is this?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: That ſhall afford us talk in th'other world.

sp.speaker: Shar.
sp.l: I fall.
sp.stage: Shar. falls: The Guards cali Treaſon, and run at the Duke: Colimsky interpoſes.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hold Villains! 'tis the Duke your General; what curſed Devil poyſon'd the Dukes ſoul with jealouſie of his brave friend?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: What fatal work is here?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: Oh heavens! Joanna, what have we done?

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: What ſhould this Tragical confuſion mean?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What Viſion have I ſeen? where am I?
Am I awake? or is't a Martial dream?
See, the Count bleeding? who hath done this deed?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: And doſt thou then lament him to my face?
Oh thou Apoſtate ſhame of Royal blood;
Is this thy gratitude for all the Martyrdoms
I've ſuffered for thy love? 'Tis I have done it and done it
To revenge my injur'd love.—And I but juſt ſhould be,
Now I have puniſh'd him, to puniſh thee;
But that, alas, 'twould be ſo poor a deed,
My very Sword would ſcorn to make thee bleed;
And if my paſſion ſhould the thing requeſt,
'Twould turn in rage againſt his Maſters breaſt.
No, I ſhall leave thee to a higher doom,
And now go waite thy lover to his Tombe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Ha! doth he go? and leave me thus in ſcorn, (proffers to go Guards, ſtop the Traytors! I le revenge my honour, and the Counts blood; in the interim, carry him out, and uſe your utmoſt skill and care about him

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Madam, he breathes, and whil • ſt there's life, there's hope, Guards ſtop the Duke.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: She'l kill the Duke; but I'le not long ſurvive him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Curland, thou dyeſt; but firſt thou muſt explain
The Myſteries of this thy proud diſdain;
Say then, what Fury did thee hither ſend,
To wound my honour, and deſtroy thy friend;
For none in Poland hath this treaſon wrought,
Nor dare they wound my honour with a thought,

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: None dare, 'twere Sacriledge to make it bleed,
None but your valiant ſelf dare do the deed;
And you are grown to that inſulting height;
You ſcorn the modeſt whiſpers of the night:
Trumpets muſt ſpeak, and Banners muſt diſplay,
And to your Lovers arms you fight your way.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This is diſtraction.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: His Ruſſian bondage hath miſlaid his reaſon.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He's mad.
I once to puniſh him had an intent,
And now I pity him; and thoſe thoughts repent:
And yet it may be thoſe diſtractions are
Only th' effect of pride, and wild deſpair:
The ſinner finds he's damn'd, and prayes in vain,
And now by blaſphemy would caſe his pain.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Yes, as a man damn'd by a falſe Religion,
When he finds all his piety in vain,
Doth curſe his gods, and wiſh he had liv'd profane;
So all my merits loſt, I now repent,
That I have been ſo fondly innocent,
That I in Muſcovy ſo vain ſhould prove,
In ſeeking Crowns and Armies for thy love;
And cruelly my heart refus'd to give,
To one who wanted it, that ſhe might live.

lg.l: What then it ſeems thy killing eyes have there
Done many murders too, as well as here;
And what If I thy tryumphs ſhould diſgrace,
And in a grave ſhould hide thy conquering face,
Where Ladies hearts it might no more ſurprize,
Nor women be in danger of thine eyes?
Sharnofsky's blood forbids to let thee live:
Yes, Curland thou ſhalt dye, it ſhall be ſeen
In this one glorious act, I am a Queen;
And let thy Soveraign title plead thy cauſe,
Let Poland talk of priviledge, or Laws,
In this great doom I uncontroul'd will be,
And trample on the State, their Laws, and thee:
And let the glory of thy Fate contain,
And ſumme up all the glory of my reign.
Guards, kill the Duke; hold, but kill him ſo,
That he may live within an hour or two: aſide
Methinks I now a little weakneſs find,
And my heart tells me, I would ſeign be kind:
Fool that I am; I weeping melt away
Even all the Crowns, and Tryumphs of the day:
The Conquerour doth quit the field and fly,
Whil'ſt the proud captive ſtands inſulting by;
That ever I ſhould play ſo weak a part,
To be entic't thus to refign my heart?
A heart, deſign'd for things ſo far above
The petty troubles and concerns of love:
Yet now led captive, can ſo proſtrate be,
To worſhip him, who ought to worſhip me:
But for theſe follies I'le my ſelf dethrone,
Forgive his ſins, but will chaſtiſe my own:
Lead to the Chappel; I'le to night—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Hold Madam, your ſoul's diſorder'd, it muſt be calm'd with penitence and prayer, before you can be fit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I cannot help it, I am but woman.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Ha! and have I wrong'd her?
What curſed charm hath lead me in this maze?
Surely I have been abus'd, young Duke of Novogrod,
Have you not told me lies? I fear you have,
And done it to revenge your friend the Prince.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Hark, he calls my Princeſs Duke of Novogrod.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Diſcover to him—

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Madam, undiſguize; and let the Duke affront you if he dares.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: Yes Sir, I've led you in this maze of jealouſie;
And done it to revenge my injur'd honour.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: A woman!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A woman!

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: Yes, and a Princeſs Madam,
Great as your ſelf by birth, greater in misfortunes;
The daughter of the mighty Czar of Muſcovy,
Become a wandring Pilgrim, hidden lies
In the poor Hermitage of this diſguize;
By Curlands treachery, now brought ſo low,
I even am aſham'd my ſelf to know.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Now I perceive the Myſtery.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: The Princeſs Paulina.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: And dar'ſt thou mention then Paulina's name,
And proudly ſtand without remorſe or ſhame?
Becauſe in war thou haſt a captive been,
Wilt thou in ſpite, thy victories begin
On Vertue, on Religion, Love, and me,
And hate my name, becauſe I pitied thee?
VVhen all the world forſook thee, I alone
Beſtow'd thy life, and made thy chains my own,
Yea more, ſo fondly I betray'd my flame,
At thy petition, I thy wife became.
When Crowns lay at my feet, I married thee,
Who hadſt no Armies, Crowns, nor liberty;
Yet promis'd one, but meant in that above,
A Crown of Martyrdom, for injur'd love.
Yet after all, (perfidious man;) to fly
And leave me in thy Chains condemn'd to die?
And when I found thee, baſely to diſclaim
Thou hadſt relation to Paulina's name?
Know Duke, I do abhor thee, and to day,
This Hand, this Steel, had ta • ne thy life away,
But that ſome power did the blow withſtand,
And when I proffer'd, did withhold my hand;
But my revenge now alters its deſign,
The death it aim'd at thee, now ſhall be mine,
Not that I dye, becauſe I grieve to part,
But thus to puniſh my rebellious heart.

sp.speaker: Jo. Al.
sp.l: Oh, ſhe hath hurt her ſelf; Oh, Madam; Madam:
sp.stage: Offers to skil • her ſelf, but Jo. Al. ſnatch the Dagger.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: What means this cruelty? oh, let me die:

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: I now perceive the maze in which they wander;
Oh, I have been too ſlow in my diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And have I wept and bled for this?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: What curſed Fantome did abuſe my ſhape?
As ever, heaven, thou'ſt regard to truth
Or innocence▪ now by thy thunder ſhew
If it was I, that wrong'd this Lady ſo.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Oh horrid, horrid!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Oh immortal Powers! and can you ſuffer this?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Prodigy!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Oh! Madam, rule your haughty paſſions,
There is a Ring of Angels made about you,
To ſee how you'l come off in this great combat.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And let 'um make a Ring—they to themſelves
The pleaſure of revenge would not deny,
Were they but fleſh and blood as well as I.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: I muſt reveal in time, before more miſchief enſues.—
Royal Madam—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ha? what art thou?

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: I'm one, whom if you pleaſe
Can in one word rectifie all miſtakes.
'Tis a deceitful marriage then breeds this
Confuſion; the Princeſs was not married
To the Duke, but to my Prince Demetrius,
He who to day was (Madam!) in your Tent
Condemn'd to die—

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: My innocence is clear'd by Miracle.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: Is Prince Demetrius here? and did he abuſe me ſo?

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Madam, he ventur'd on ſo grand an enterpriſe,
Partly t' allay the torment of his love,
And partly for revenge upon your Father,
Who having promis'd you, as a reward to him,
For taking the Duke priſoner, ſlighted his Royal word,
Upon the news of the King o' Polands death,
And proffers you to the Duke, with a great army,
Only in hopes to make you Queen o' Poland;
The Duke indeed did nobly ſlight the proffers.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So Count Sharnofsky ſaid.
VVhat have I done to wound that gallant man?

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: My fiery Prince reſenting the affront,
As proudly as the Emperour did his,
'Twixt rage and love, did by a wile entice you
Unto the Caſtle where the Duke was pris'ner,
Pretending danger; penitence and love,
And (if you if you remember) married you in the dark,
Becauſe he would not truſt (as he pretended)
The Prieſt himſelf with ſuch a dangerous ſecret.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Amazement!

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: And e're you could diſcover the miſtake,
You fled away in a fright, and ere you went,
Brib'd the Cipier for the Dukes liberty;
Then he in innocence forſaking you,
And you as innocent in purſuing him,
Occaſion'd this unhappineſs.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Heavens, 'twas this the Cardinal took advanage on to breed all this diſorder.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Now all's come to light.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: How have I been abus'd? unhappy I, born to misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: See, my Prince is here!
sp.stage: Enter Demetius and Landlord ſtrugling with the Guard.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: I think my Landlord, the Prince perhaps was the other ſtrang lodg'd in the ſame houſe: petty humour of fortune!

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Come honeſt Cardinal Bembo, doſt thou not remember
I made thee a Cardinal at the Councel o' Trent,
Haſt thou forgot Pope Pauls great Toe, boy?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Slave, ſhall I ſtay here all night?

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Well what would you ſee? all's done.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Nay, I told you Id'e get you in, if any body could; the Rogues all know me as well as a beggar knows his Clap-diſh.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Curland, have I found thee? 'tis not thy friends,
Nor the Queens Guards that ſhall protect thee.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Hold Sir, all's well.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Not till Curland or I fall.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Why, what a mad fellow's this? draw in the preſence; why Sirrrah, do you know where you are, you malapert lad you? I ſhall be hang'd for bringing in a quarrelſome Jackanapes, if I had known, I would ha' kept him at home, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: O! hold, and turn your eyes on that ſad object that there lies weeping, bleeding for your crimes.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: My Princeſs, I'm in a trance; oh bloody Viſion! what curſed hand hath done this wretched deed?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: 'Tis you have done it, oh Demetrius,
How have you injur'd me? what horrid dangers
And miſeries have you expos'd me to?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: This young man hath been in a ſcuffle, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: I'de loſt my life under my Fathers anger,
Had it not been for this good Count Alexey,
Who had the charge of me, and help't me away;
And now in paſſion I have chas'd the Duke,
Thinking him guilty of forſaking me
His lawful Wife, and made him kill his friend,
Injure his Princeſs; and had fallen himſelf
By my revenge, this Steel had pierc't his breaſt;
But heaven to whom his innocence was known,
Thus made me turn the blow againſt my own.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: What's the meaning of all this blind ſtory?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And have I injur'd thus the Duke, and you?
What miſeries, what torments are my due?
Firſt by ſome ſlave, or Villain, let me dye,
And when I'm dead, then ſtab my memory.
By my own hand, or your's, to dye, would be
A death too brave for ſuch a Fiend as me:
And when I'm buried, to my Grave repair,
And throw in ſcorn my aſhes in the air:
But leſt you prove unjuſt, and pardon all
My horrid crimes, thus at your feet I fall.
sp.stage: profers to fall an his ſword, and is prevented by Ladiſl Paul. Bat.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: What art mad? wilt thou kill thy ſelf, ſweetheart? bleſs me, he makes my heart ake; take the ſword from him, fie upon't, who lets ſuch young fools ha' ſwords, that don't know how to uſe 'um?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Hold Prince Demetrius! live, your wife Paulina doth beg it of you.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Your wife Paulina; what, I warrant this young man is that young mans wife; why ſure my houſe was inchanted to day, lodg'd Princes, and Dukes, like Mummers and Maſqueraders; and Women and Wenches in mens cloathes, and Cloakbags, and ſcufflings, and they kill one another▪ and they'r alive again, and this, and that, and I know not what; here's work indeed.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And can you pardon me my kindeſt Princeſs?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Yes, my dear Demetrius, I have charity enough to pardon you, and vertue enough to love you.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Bleſſed minute; I ſhall dye with happineſs.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And I with joy.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Now generous Ladiſlaus, can you forgive me?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: My Princely friend.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I,—hug,—but you'r but a couple o' Knaves both on yo •

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: Great Madam, may not we embrace, as well as our 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yes Madam, and perhaps with an affection as generous as theirs

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Celeſtial ſight!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: The Charm that rais'd this 'o tempeſt confuſion
Is now undone, the horrid Spectre's vaniſht;
All ends in friendſhip, let it end in glory;
Love now is Crown'd, let honour be ſo too;
Let's place the Crown upon the head of him
Who in a thouſand fields hath purchas'd it.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: With all my heart truly, though I muſt tell you, you'r none of th'honeſteſt to run away and pay me no rent.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Great Duke, it is decree'd you are our King,
And you our Queen.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Long live Ladiſlaus King of Poland, and Duke of Curland.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Long live Juliana Queen of Poland, and Dutcheſs of Curland.

sp.speaker: Lad. Jul.
sp.p: My Lords, we thank you all for this great honour, And ſhall endeavour ſtill to make this Crown Rather the Kingdoms glory than our own.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Your humble ſervant; no body queſtions it; well now an't pleaſe your Majeſty—

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Go, I forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Forgive me; thank you heartily: I come to dun him for money, and he cries he forgives me; right Courtier I'faith; but if you forgive me, I won't forgive you: in the firſt place, for cheating me of five thouſand Crowns, but that I'le take no notice of (aſide Why Sir, for my Rent, and ſeveral other courteſies, as procuring, conniving, angling for Trouts; no courteſie in this age; come, come Sir, a feeling, a feeling, and I'le take no notice, otherwiſe my tongue doth naturally hang ſo looſe,—but nothing is better for it than a little Aurum Potabile.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: This fellow is ſtrangely impertinent.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Beſides, do I deſerve nothing for my honeſty for concealing you? I knew you well enough.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: I doubt Landlord, if you had, my head had not ſtuck faſt upon my ſhoulders.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: It may be Sir, if I had been put to a great ſtraight indeed, I might have borrowed a little money upon your Noſe, or ſo—

sp.speaker: Lad
sp.p: Rid me Theodore of this fellow, and give him a hundred Dollars.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Thank your Mijeſty.
sp.stage: Enter one of the Guard who whiſpers Colimsky.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sir, the Grand Marſhal and the other Lords deſire to have admiſſion to your Majeſty t' implore your Grace and pardon. to the King.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Bring them in.
sp.stage: Enter Guard with Oſſolinsky, Caſſonofsky, and Lubomi • sky as priſoners.

sp.speaker: Oſſo. Caſſo.
sp.p: Heaven Crown your Majeſty with a long and happy Reign.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Oh my good Lords; what ha' you chang'd your tunes?
sp.l: But you poor men ſung but the Card'nals Notes:
My Lord, forgive'um. Thou malicious Count
That wouldſt have murder'd me in my Tent to day
And mixt my blood with my great Fathers aſhes,
Know ſlave, ſome of my Guards ſhou'd ſtrike thee dead,
But that thy very baſeneſs ſaves thy head.
Who merits my revenge and hate, muſt prove
As brave and great, as he who gains my love.
I pardon thee, retire out of my ſight—
And now go home, repent thy crimes and ſee
If heaven will be generous like me.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: My Lords, you have your pardons; your Lives and Fortunes we ſhall not touch, your Offices and Governments we muſt beſtow on men of better maxims: Count Colimsky, the Batton of Grand Marſhal we confer on you: Their Governments and Palatinates we ſhall conſider of.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: I'le beg a command of the King for you, good Count Alexey.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: No Madam, I'le ſerve none but your Highneſs; let me but live in your favour, 'tis all the glory I am ambitious of.

sp.speaker: Caſſo.
sp.p: Now will I go home and hang one half of my Slaves, ſtarve the other; kick my wife out o'doors, be drunk nine and fifty hours together, breed a mutiny at home, and a Rebellion in the Kingdom; and at laſt looſe my head for my pains, and there's an end of good Count Caſſ • nofsky.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Now let us all go viſit my brave friend.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.p: Great Sir, I now came from him, his wound is ſearch't, and is found not ſo dangerous as firſt was fear'd; at his return to ſenſe, he ſeem'd amaz'd, as having loſt all memory, how he came wounded ſo, nor was he concern'd, but only enquir'd about the Queens health.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Brave friend!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: The Count was ever generous.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Lights for the King and Queen.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Thus do our Fortunes lead us blindly on,
And to be happy we are firſt undone;
And thus the mighty ſtorms have all combin'd,
To caſt thee on the ſhore which I deſign'd.
And now I'm bleſt with happineſs above,
My own ambition with a Crown and Love.

div.head: The EPILOGƲE ſpoken by Paulina, and Landlord.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: NOw Gentlemen, a word.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: How now, you Lout,
What are you ſpeaking?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Now th'aſt put me out,
I know not what it was.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: Oh, I can tell!
The Epilogue; yet it becomes you well,
You Gentlemen! and why I pray to them,
What do the Ladies merit no eſteem?
Good Sirs! I know not whether 'tis your due,
But Poets ſtill direct themſelves to you:
Don't the Foppes know in this and every age,
'Tis beauty rules the World, much more the Stage.
When you ha' done your beſt, the Seribling Clowns
Lye at the mercy of the Ladies frowns:
And not a Critick of you all but knows,
No reparties are half ſo ſharp as thoſe.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Why prethee, 'twas the women wits I meant,
'Tis not the men I'm ſure that pay my Rent;
For they are grown ſo Hect'ring now adayes
They kick my Cuſtomers, and damn their Playes,
That I am ruin'd by your Critick Blades;
What dee think I keep Fidlers, Men, and Maids
For nothing? and beſides that dreadful charge,
I'm building a new houſe that's brave and large;
If you'r ſo curious as y'ave been before,
I muſt e'en lay the Key under the Door.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: Prethee ha' done?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: No Sir, I've more to ſay
Then if the Liquor I ha br • ach't to day
B • good, commend it, but if it be dull,
I'faith e'en da • m, and ramm your belly full.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.l: Away rude Fool! fair Engliſh Diett then,
Senate of Ladies, lower Houſe of Men,
I bumbly pray decree before you go
If Marriage like mine be right or no,
At leaſt reſolve in pity of my pain,
To ſit to morrow on the ſame again.
